chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect mastitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Suspect mastitis in a woman who presents with:
    • A painful breast.
    • Fever and/or general malaise.
    • A tender, red, swollen, and hard area of the breast, usually in a wedge-shaped distribution.
  • Be aware that the symptoms and signs of non-lactational mastitis may mimic breast cancer or a breast abscess:
    • Periductal mastitis may present with periareolar inflammation (with or without an associated mass), an established abscess, nipple retraction at the site of the diseased duct, central breast pain, and/or greenish discharge from the nipple.
    • Granulomatous mastitis may present with a firm, unilateral breast mass, breast distortion, nipple retraction, skin thickening, axillar adenopathy, ulceration, or a large area (or areas) of infection with multiple simultaneous peripheral abscesses.
      • Note: the clinical features of granulomatous mastitis overlap with those of breast cancer and a biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis.
  • It is not possible to reliably distinguish between non-infectious and infectious mastitis based on clinical features. However, features that may raise suspicion of infection include:
    • A nipple fissure that looks infected.
    • Purulent discharge.
    • Influenza-like symptoms and pyrexia lasting for longer than 24 hours.
    • Considerable breast discomfort.
    • For lactating women, features of infection may include:
      • Symptoms not improving (or worsening) after 12–24 hours despite effective milk removal.
      • Positive breast milk culture. For information on when to arrange culture of the breast milk, see the section on Investigations.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Clinical features of mastitis

  • The information on the general clinical features of mastitis is based on expert opinion in the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Mastitis. Causes and management [WHO, 2000], the Health Service Executive Ireland Mastitis: Fact sheet for Health Care Professionals [Health Service Executive Ireland, 2017], the BMJ Best Practice guideline Mastitis and breast abscess [BMJ Best Practice, 2020], and in review articles on the management of lactational mastitis [Betzold, 2007; Dixon, 2011].

Additional clinical features of non-lactational mastitis

  • The information on additional clinical features of periductal mastitis is based on expert opinion in review articles on mastitis [Blackmon, 2020] and the management of breast infections [Dixon, 2011; Dixon, 2013].
  • The information on additional clinical features of granulomatous mastitis is based on expert opinion in review articles on the management of breast infections [Dixon, 2011; Dixon, 2013], mastitis [Blackmon, 2020], and granulomatous mastitis [Guray, 2006; Hovanessian Larsen, 2009; Vinayagam, 2009; Patel, 2010].

Distinguishing between granulomatous mastitis and breast cancer

  • The advice that due to overlapping clinical features, a biopsy is required to distinguish between granulomatous mastitis and breast cancer is based on expert opinion in a review article on mastitis [Blackmon, 2020], which also states that ultrasound and mammography are not adequate to distinguish granulomatous mastitis from breast malignancy.

Distinguishing between infectious and non-infectious mastitis

  • The information on clinical features that may be suggestive of infectious mastitis is partly based on the criteria that the WHO use for starting an antibiotic [WHO, 2000; WHO, 2009]. While CKS pragmatically suggests that if these features are present, an infectious cause is more likely, it should be borne in mind that it is impossible to reliably distinguish clinically between infectious and non-infectious mastitis.
  • Expert opinion in the BMJ Best Practice guideline Mastitis and breast abscess is that purulent discharge is usually indicative of a breast infection [BMJ Best Practice, 2020].
  • Expert opinion in the Guidelines and Audit Implementation Network (GAIN) Guidelines on the treatment, management, and prevention of mastitis [GAIN, 2009] is that:
    • Influenza-like symptoms and pyrexia are more likely to last for longer than 24 hours in women with infectious mastitis compared with non-infectious mastitis.
    • Women with infectious mastitis are likely to experience considerable breast discomfort compared with women with non-infectious mastitis.
